edge: The film is a black comedy.
The film is a crime thriller.
The character played by Ayushmann Khurrana in the film is a blind piano player.
The retired actor portrayed in the film becomes a murder victim.
Tabu is an actress who appears in the film.
Anil Dhawan is an actor who appears in the film.
The film was shot in Pune.
Sriram Raghavan is the director of the film.
Arijit Biswas is one of the screenwriters for the film.
Pooja Ladha Surti is one of the screenwriters for the film.
Yogesh Chandekar is one of the screenwriters for the film.
K. U. Mohanan was replaced by Hemanth M. Rao as the director of photography during the filming process.
Amit Trivedi composed songs for the film.
Jaideep Sahni wrote the lyrics for some of the songs in the film.
Raftaar and Girish Nakod co-wrote the title song as guest composers.
feigning ignorance and continuing to play the piano
seeing Manohar hiding in the bathroom during cleaning of crime scene
Simi overhears Mrs. D'Sa talking to a police officer about seeing an unknown man going to the Sinhas' flat
forcing Akash to admit faking his blindness by pulling out a gun
Furious and heartbroken, Sophie leaves Akash after a neighbour's child records a video of Akash fully able to see and shows it to Sophie.
Manohar comes to Akash's house to kill him after Simi arranges things to look like she and Akash had slept together.
Dr. Swami decides to spare Akash when he reveals he has information that will make them millions at an illegal organ harvesting clinic.

['Simi arranges things to look like she and Akash had slept together.', "Akash wakes up in an illegal organ harvesting clinic with Simi as they were both kidnapped by Dr. Swami's assistants Murli and Sakhu."]
After Akash reveals the information that will make them millions, Murli and Sakhu double-cross him and tie him up with Simi.
Murli is accidentally shot and killed by Manohar in an elevator.

['Swami reveals that Simi has a rare blood type and that her organs would sell for millions.', 'Swami enters; after a brief fight, he and Akash knock Simi out, tie her up in the boot of a car, and drive away.', "Swami plans to use Simi's corneas to restore Akash's sight."]
A neighbour's child, suspicious of Akash's blindness, records a video of Akash fully able to see and shows it to Sophie.
After Simi arranges things to look like she and Akash had slept together, Manohar comes to Akash's house to kill Akash.
['As Sophie arrives, Simi arranges things to look like she and Akash had slept together.', 'Dr. Swami decides to spare Akash when he reveals he has information that will make them millions.']
After Simi arranges things to look like she and Akash had slept together, Sophie leaves Akash angry and heartbroken.
Simi overpowered Swami and seized the wheel, causing a car accident in which she died.
After listening to Akash's story, Sophie tells him that he should have accepted Swami's offer.
Sriram Raghavan was inspired by the French short film L'Accordeur to create his own story.
Raghavan stopped writing his script when he heard about another film, Kaabil, which is also about a blind person. He was unsure if having two films about blind people would be 'crazy'.

The idea of a blind pianist performing while a body is being dumped and a crime scene cleaned up fascinated Raghavan, who had written a similar scene for his previous film, Agent Vinod (2012), in which a blind girl plays the piano while surrounded by mayhem. This concept inspired the main character of our film.

Raghavan wrote the script with Arijit Biswas, Yogesh Chandekar, Rao and Pooja Ladha Surti. He gave the story idea to Varun Dhawan while they were working on Badlapur but Dhawan became busy with other films and the script was left unfinished.

node_2: raghavan and biswas were unhappy while translating the dialogue from english to hindi because they thought in english.
edge: The main character is a blind pianist and their dialogues were initially written in English but had to be translated into Hindi.
Raghavan told Biswas to write the dramatic dialogue in Bengali, which was 'at least the Indian idiom' as they were unhappy while translating the dialogue from English to Hindi.
Surti wrote another version of the dialogue because her Hindi was better than that of the others.
One of his friends was in a situation similar to one in the film; he then realised old Hindi films use 'piano songs' and decided make the blind pianist the main character.
Raghavan cited the 1996 film Fargo and the eponymous television series as an inspiration, calling them 'realistic and yet ... bizarre'.
contacted Raghavan, expressing interest in working on the film after hearing about it from casting directors Mukesh Chhabra and Girdhar Swami.
conducted screen tests of the scene in which the protagonist wakes up blind with Ayushmann Khurrana to see the difference in his body language.
met several blind students and observed 'how [a blind pianist] plays, conducts and moves his hands'.
played the piano in the film after studying piano for four hours daily under Akshay Verma, a pianist based in Los Angeles.
did not use a body double in the film while playing the piano.
Raghavan told Khurrana not to watch films with a blind protagonist and took him to the National School of the Blind.

node_2: a special lens that impairs vision by around 80 percent
edge: Khurrana was given a pair of special lenses that impaired his vision by around 80 percent.
After wearing the black glasses, his vision was affected by 90 percent and he shot the entire film like that.
Several scenes were improvised.
Raghavan called Radhika Apte, who agreed to play Khurranaâ€™s love interest.
Tabu was Raghavan's first choice for Simi. They 'kept developing [the character] as it went.'

node_2: a former actor, a version of himself
edge: Anil Dhawan played a former actor, a version of himself.

According to him, Andhadhun is not a whodunit; '... The audience knows all along what's happening and why. It's the characters who don't.' Raghavan said he wanted to make a 'fun sort of thriller' to follow Badlapur.
Andhadhun was shot in Pune; filming took 44 days over more than a year because none of the actors were available for a long shooting schedule.
Principal photography began in June 2017 and ended on 17 July 2018.
Raghavan and the film's director of photography K. U. Mohanan decided to 'restrict everything to Akash's point of view' so the audience could see what Akash sees.
There were no close-ups in the piano-playing scene, which was extensively rehearsed with several assistants to fit its timing into the four-minute piano piece.
It was not rehearsed with the actors; Raghavan told them to 'just do the scene' and gave them a time frame; 'We didn't want it to look practiced; we needed that uncertainty'.
Raghavan called Andhadhun 'a fun film in the macabre sense of the word', with moments of 'wickedness and brutality'.
Raghavan wanted the film to have an open ending and considered several options.
The production teams were apprehensive about the audience acceptance of an English title but Raghavan persuaded them because they felt it would 'alienate people'.
The producers felt an English title would 'alienate people', and the title was changed because of this.
The title is a play on the words 'andhadhun' and 'blind tune and trance'.
Vocals for some songs in the soundtrack were provided by Raftaar.
Amit Trivedi composed most of the music for the soundtrack.
Jaideep Sahni wrote the lyrics for some songs in the album.
Ayushmann Khurrana provided vocals for some songs, along with Raftaar and Arijit Singh.
The soundtrack was released by Zee Music Company.
Daniel B. George composed the background score for the movie.
The film was scheduled for release on August 31, 2018, but it was postponed until October 5. The producers announced the delay in a trailer.

Originally, Raghavan wanted the film's trailer to only contain sounds because it is the story of a blind man, but the studio was 'shocked' at his suggestion. After several discussions, they agreed on a trailer.
The film was released on 800 screens across India.
The film is available on Netflix and JioCinema.
Tabu was honoured at the 2019 Indian Film Festival of Los Angeles for her role in Andhadhun.
The film was released in China as Piano Player on April 3, 2019.
The film was released in South Korea on August 28, 2019, and was screened in over 90 theatres.
On Rotten Tomatoes, Andhadhun holds a rating of 100% based on 15 reviews, with an average rating of 7.7/10.

node_1: raghavan creates a world interchangeably familiar and pulpy
edge: Shilajit Mitra's review in The New Indian Express where he rated the film 4 out of 5 stars and mentioned Raghavan's style of creating a world that is both familiar and pulpy.

Sushant Mehta's review in India Today where he mentioned that Raghavan's ability to shock and make the audience laugh during these moments defines his 'unique brand of cinema'.

node_1: strong flavour of the coen brothers
edge: Nandini Ramnath's statement in Scroll.in where she mentioned that Andhadhun has a 'strong flavour of the Coen brothers'.
Nandini Ramnath's statement in Scroll.in where she mentioned that Andhadhun has 'nods to Raghavan's longstanding interest'.
The dynamics of the perfect crime are a notable aspect of the Coen brothers' distinctive style in this film.
This film showcases enough nods to the Coen brothers' longstanding interest in pulp detective stories, as evidenced by their previous works.
This film represents the flavor of the Coen brothers at their peak.
The film explores the themes of the perfect crime, which have been a consistent focus in Raghavan's works over time.
Raghavan's longstanding interest in hustlers and flimflam artists, a common feature of pulp detective stories, is also evident in this film.
The film's runtime, while long, slides into place as smoothly as one of Akash's piano pieces.
Anupama Chopra's review highlights the occurrence of murder in Andhadhun, which is 'deliciously twisted' and cannot be looked away from.
Anupama Chopra's review implies that there is betrayal in Andhadhun, which goes hand-in-hand with murder and other twisted happenings.
Anupama Chopra's review suggests that there is sex in Andhadhun, but it is not explicitly mentioned and is rather encompassed by the term 'twisted happenings'.
Udita Jhunjhunwala of Mint praises Akshay Khurrana's performance in Andhadhun, calling it a 'taut performance that balances vulnerability with craftiness'
Udita Jhunjhunwala of Mint asserts that Tabu runs away with the show in Andhadhun.
Shaheen Irani of Deccan Chronicle highlights the presence of dark humour in Andhadhun, which is kept 'intact' by Sriram.
Namrata Joshi asserts that Namrata Joshi is always a step ahead of the viewers in Andhadhun's cat-and-mouse game.
